docs.snippet: President Eisenhower's latest letter to Soviet Premier Khrushchev represents an important step forward in the effort to secure progress toward ending nuclear tests. Whether this progress will actually be achieved now depends on the Soviet Union....

docs.abstract: State Dept cancels all outstanding visas for re-exam; M J McDermott comments; repts no decision on Spaniards and Argentines but says Yugoslavs may be barred; Justice Dept exemption powers discussed; all aliens entering under State Dept exch-of-persons program to be exempt; Immigration Service says ban affects citizens of totalitarian nations sent by non-govt orgns as observers to UN; conflict with US-UN pact seen

headline.main: Resort Fights to Keep Gas Lamps That Generate Its Income

docs.snippet: Few measures could bring home more quickly to large numbers of our people the seriousness of the struggle ahead than the new order of the Office of Production Management stopping all retail sales of automotive vehicles, as a preliminary to a ban o...
docs.lead_paragraph: Few measures could bring home more quickly to large numbers of our people the seriousness of the struggle ahead than the new order of the Office of Production Management stopping all retail sales of automotive vehicles, as a preliminary to a ban on the future manufacture of these vehicles for ordinary civilian use.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   Having spent a month in Izumo last summer, my husband and I enjoyed Henry Scott Stokes's piece on the ''Home of Japan's Shinto Gods'' (Travel, Feb. 25). Izumo City is six miles or so from Izumo Taisha (as the shrine is called), an...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Having spent a month in Izumo last summer, my husband and I enjoyed Henry Scott Stokes's piece on the ''Home of Japan's Shinto Gods'' (Travel, Feb. 25). Izumo City is six miles or so from Izumo Taisha (as the shrine is called), and I would recommend a visit to this town of some 80,000 which is very different from the densely populated cities of so many other parts of Japan.

docs.snippet: MONTREAL -- The strict curbs on pleasure travel in the United States and the dollar area just imposed by the Canadian Government on its citizens are causing a hurried shuffle of winter vacation plans. In order to conserve a dwindling supply of Uni...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTREAL -- The strict curbs on pleasure travel in the United States and the dollar area just imposed by the Canadian Government on its citizens are causing a hurried shuffle of winter vacation plans. In order to conserve a dwindling supply of United States dollars the Government now permits Canadians to take out of the country for pleasure trips only $150 annually.
docs.abstract: US expected to be hit by Canadian $150 limit

headline.main: U.S. WILL FEEL CANADA TRAVEL CURB
